16N.2.sl.TZ0.4a.excerpt: State the nuclear symbol notation,               Z    A    X, for magnesium-26.
specification: Magnesium is a group 2 metal which exists as a number of isotopes and forms many compounds.

questions.content: State the nuclear symbol notation, \({}_Z^AX\), for magnesium-26.
questions.label: a

questions.content:
Mass spectroscopic analysis of a sample of magnesium gave the following results:



Calculate the relative atomic mass, Ar, of this sample of magnesium to two decimal places.
questions.label: b
markscheme:
Award [2] for correct final answer.
Do not accept data booklet value (24.31).

questions.content: Magnesium burns in air to form a white compound, magnesium oxide. Formulate an equation for the reaction of magnesium oxide with water.
questions.label: c

questions.content: Describe the trend in acid-base properties of the oxides of period 3, sodium to chlorine.
questions.label: d
markscheme:
Accept “alkali/alkaline” for “basic”.
Accept “oxides of Na and Mg: basic AND oxide of Al: amphoteric” for M1.
Accept “oxides of non-metals/Si to Cl acidic” for M2.
Do not accept just “become more acidic”

questions.content: In addition to magnesium oxide, magnesium forms another compound when burned in air. Suggest the formula of this compound
questions.label: e

questions.content: Describe the structure and bonding in solid magnesium oxide.
questions.label: f
markscheme:
«3-D/giant» regularly repeating arrangement «of ions»
OR
lattice «of ions»
Accept “giant” for M1, unless “giant covalent” stated.

electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions
OR
electrostatic attraction between Mg2+ and O2– ions
Do not accept “ionic” without description.

questions.content:
Magnesium chloride can be electrolysed.


Deduce the half-equations for the reactions at each electrode when molten magnesium chloride is electrolysed, showing the state symbols of the products. The melting points of magnesium and magnesium chloride are 922 K and 987 K respectively.


Anode (positive electrode):


Cathode (negative electrode):
questions.label: g
markscheme:
Penalize missing/incorrect state symbols at Cl2 and Mg once only.
Award [1 max] if equations are at wrong electrodes.
Accept Mg (g).

17M.2.sl.TZ1.2c.excerpt: State the number of protons, neutrons and electrons in the                     22              48            Ti   atom.
specification: Titanium is a transition metal.
TiCl4 reacts with water and the resulting titanium(IV) oxide can be used as a smoke screen.

questions.content: Describe the bonding in metals.
questions.label: a
markscheme: between «a lattice of» metal/positive ions/cations AND «a sea of» delocalizedelectrons

questions.content:
Titanium exists as several isotopes. The mass spectrum of a sample of titanium gave the following data:



Calculate the relative atomic mass of titanium to two decimal places.
questions.label: b
markscheme: Answer must have two decimal placeswith a value from 47.90 to 48.00.

questions.content: State the number of protons, neutrons and electrons in the \({}_{22}^{48}{\text{Ti}}\) atom.
questions.label: c

questions.content: State the full electron configuration of the \({}_{22}^{48}{\text{Ti}}\)2+ ion.
questions.label: d.i

questions.content: Explain why an aluminium-titanium alloy is harder than pure aluminium.
questions.label: d.ii
markscheme:
titanium atoms/ions distort the regular arrangement of atoms/ions
OR
titanium atoms/ions are a different size to aluminium «atoms/ions»

questions.content: State the type of bonding in potassium chloride which melts at 1043 K.
questions.label: e.i

questions.content: A chloride of titanium, TiCl4, melts at 248 K. Suggest why the melting point is so much lower than that of KCl.
questions.label: e.ii
markscheme: Accept specific examples of weakbonds such as London/dispersion andvan der Waals.

questions.content: Formulate an equation for this reaction.
questions.label: f.i
markscheme: Award M2 if products are HCl and acompound of Ti and O.

questions.content: Suggest one disadvantage of using this smoke in an enclosed space.
questions.label: f.ii
markscheme:
HCl causes breathing/respiratory problems
OR
HCl is an irritant
OR
HCl is toxic
OR
HCl has acidic vapour
OR
HCl is corrosive

17M.2.sl.TZ2.1b.excerpt: Naturally occurring silver is composed of two stable isotopes, 107Ag and 109Ag.The relative atomic mass of silver is 107.87. Show that isotope 107Ag is more abundant.
specification: There are many oxides of silver with the formula AgxOy. All of them decompose into their elements when heated strongly.

questions.content: After heating 3.760 g of a silver oxide 3.275 g of silver remained. Determine the empirical formula of AgxOy.
questions.label: a.i
markscheme: «\(\frac{{0.03036}}{{0.03031}} \approx 1\) / ratio of Ag to O approximately 1 : 1, so»
Award [1 max] for correct empiricalformula if method not shown.

questions.content: Suggest why the final mass of solid obtained by heating 3.760 g of AgxOy may be greater than 3.275 g giving one design improvement for your proposed suggestion. Ignore any possible errors in the weighing procedure.
questions.label: a.ii
markscheme:
temperature too low
OR
heating time too short
OR
oxide not decomposed completely
heat sample to constant mass «for three or more trials»
If M1 as per markscheme, M2 can onlybe awarded for constant masstechnique.
Accept "soot deposition" (M1) and anysuitable way to reduce it (for M2).
Award [1 max] for reference to impurityAND design improvement.

questions.content:
Naturally occurring silver is composed of two stable isotopes, 107Ag and 109Ag.


The relative atomic mass of silver is 107.87. Show that isotope 107Ag is more abundant.
questions.label: b
markscheme:
Ar closer to 107/less than 108 «so more 107Ag»
OR
Ar less than the average of (107 +109) «so more 107Ag»

questions.content:
Some oxides of period 3, such as Na2O and P4O10, react with water. A spatula measure of each oxide was added to a separate 100 cm3 flask containing distilled water and a few drops of bromothymol blue indicator.


The indicator is listed in section 22 of the data booklet.


Deduce the colour of the resulting solution and the chemical formula of the product formed after reaction with water for each oxide.
questions.label: c.i
markscheme: Do not accept name for the products.

questions.content: Explain the electrical conductivity of molten Na2O and P4O10.
questions.label: c.ii
markscheme: «molten» Na2O has mobile ions/charged particles AND conducts electricity
«molten» P4O10 does not have mobile ions/charged particles AND does notconduct electricity/is poor conductor of electricity
Do not award marks without concept ofmobile charges being present.
Award [1 max] if type of bonding orelectrical conductivity correctly identifiedin each compound.

questions.content: Outline the model of electron configuration deduced from the hydrogen line emission spectrum (Bohr’s model).
questions.label: d
markscheme:
energy levels converge/get closer together at higher energies
OR
energy levels converge with distance from the nucleus
Accept appropriate diagram for M1, M2or both.
Do not give marks for answers that referto the lines in the spectrum.

specification: Chlorine undergoes many reactions.

2.67 g of manganese(IV) oxide was added to 200.0 cm3 of 2.00 mol dm-3 HCl.
MnO2 (s)+4HCl (aq)→Cl2 (g)+2H2O (l)+MnCl2 (aq)

Chlorine gas reacts with water to produce hypochlorous acid and hydrochloric acid.
Cl2 (g)+H2O (l)⇌HClO (aq)+HCl (aq)
CCl2F2 is a common chlorofluorocarbon, CFC.

questions.content: State the full electron configuration of the chlorine atom.
questions.label: a(i)

questions.content: State, giving a reason, whether the chlorine atom or the chloride ion has a larger radius.
questions.label: a(ii)
markscheme: Accept Cl- AND has an extra electron.

questions.content: Outline why the chlorine atom has a smaller atomic radius than the sulfur atom.
questions.label: a(iii)
markscheme: Cl has a greater nuclear charge/number of protons/Zeff «causing a stronger pull on the outer electrons» ✔

questions.content:
The mass spectrum of chlorine is shown.



NIST Mass Spectrometry Data Center Collection © 2014 copyright by the U.S. Secretary of Commerce on behalf of the United States of America. All rights reserved.


Outline the reason for the two peaks at m/z=35 and 37.
questions.label: a(iv)

questions.content: Explain the presence and relative abundance of the peak at m/z=74.
questions.label: a(v)
markscheme:
chlorine-37 is the least abundant «isotope»
OR
low probability of twoCl37 «isotopes» occurring in a molecule ✔

questions.content: Calculate the amount, in mol, of manganese(IV) oxide added.
questions.label: b(i)

questions.content: Determine the limiting reactant, showing your calculations.
questions.label: b(ii)
markscheme: Accept other valid methods of determining the limiting reactant in M2.

questions.content: Determine the excess amount, in mol, of the other reactant.
questions.label: b(iii)

questions.content: Calculate the volume of chlorine, in dm3, produced if the reaction is conducted at standard temperature and pressure (STP). Use section 2 of the data booklet.
questions.label: b(iv)

questions.content: State the oxidation state of manganese in MnO2 and MnCl2.
questions.label: b(v)

questions.content: Deduce, referring to oxidation states, whether MnO2 is an oxidizing or reducing agent.
questions.label: b(vi)
markscheme: oxidizing agent AND oxidation state of Mn changes from +4 to +2/decreases ✔

questions.label: c(i)

questions.content: State the formula of the conjugate base of hypochlorous acid.
questions.label: c(ii)

questions.content: Calculate the concentration of H+ (aq) in a HClO aq solution with a pH=3.61.
questions.label: c(iii)

questions.content: State the type of reaction occurring when ethane reacts with chlorine to produce chloroethane.
questions.label: d(i)
markscheme: Do not accept electrophilic or nucleophilic substitution.

questions.content: Predict, giving a reason, whether ethane or chloroethane is more reactive.
questions.label: d(ii)
markscheme:
chloroethane ANDC–Cl bond is weaker/324 kJ mol−1 thanC–H bond/414 kJ mol−1
OR
chloroethane AND contains a polar bond ✔

questions.label: d(iii)
markscheme: Accept use ofC2H5Cl andC2H5OH/C2H6O in the equation.

questions.content: Deduce the nucleophile for the reaction in d(iii).
questions.label: d(iv)

questions.content: Ethoxyethane (diethyl ether) can be used as a solvent for this conversion. Draw the structural formula of ethoxyethane
questions.label: d(v)

questions.content: Deduce the number of signals and their chemical shifts in the H1 NMR spectrum of ethoxyethane. Use section 27 of the data booklet.
questions.label: d(vi)
markscheme: Award [1 max] for two incorrect chemical shifts.

questions.content: Calculate the percentage by mass of chlorine in CCl2F2.
questions.label: e(i)

questions.content: Comment on how international cooperation has contributed to the lowering of CFC emissions responsible for ozone depletion.
questions.label: e(ii)
markscheme:
research «collaboration» for alternative technologies «to replace CFCs»
OR
technologies «developed»/data could be shared
OR
political pressure/Montreal Protocol/governments passing legislations ✔
Do not accept any reference to CFC as greenhouse gas or product of fossil fuel combustion.
Accept reference to specific measures, such as agreement on banning use/manufacture of CFCs.

specification:
Fast moving helium nuclei (4He2+) were fired at a thin piece of gold foil with most passing undeflected but a few deviating largely from their path. The diagram illustrates this historic experiment.

Figure from PPLATO / FLAP (Flexible Learning Approach To Physics), http://www.met.reading.ac.uk/pplato2/h-flap/phys8_1.html#top 1996 The Open University and The University of Reading.

questions.content: Suggest what can be concluded about the gold atom from this experiment.
questions.label: a
markscheme:
most of the atom is empty space
OR
the space between nuclei is much larger than 4He2+ particles
OR
nucleus/centre is «very» small «compared to the size of the atom» ✔
Very few 4He2+ deviating largely from their path:

nucleus/centre is positive «and repels 4He2+ particles»
OR
nucleus/centre is «more» dense/heavy «than 4He2+ particles and deflects them»
OR
nucleus/centre is «very» small «compared to the size of the atom» ✔
Do not accept the same reason for both M1 and M2.
Accept “most of the atom is an electron cloud” for M1.
Do not accept only “nucleus repels 4He2+ particles” for M2.

questions.content:
Subsequent experiments showed electrons existing in energy levels occupying various orbital shapes.


Sketch diagrams of 1s, 2s and 2p.
questions.label: b(i)
markscheme: one or more 2p orbital(s) as figure(s) of 8 shape(s) of any orientation (px, py pz) ✔

questions.content: State the electron configuration of copper.
questions.label: b(ii)
